com.greenfabric.util
Class QuoteTool

java.lang.Object
  com.greenfabric.util.QuoteTool
public class QuoteTool
extends java.lang.Object

This class provides a 'quoting' service. This is necessary because 'special' characters have to be quoted before they can be included in an SQL query, or used in other special contexts.

It's also a small collaborative effort - experience from different people with different databases can be added here to help others out making cross-platform applications.

Usage Example:

   String text    = "original text";
   QuoteTool tool = new QuoteTool(QuoteTool.SQL_SERVER);
   System.out.printn("quoted text = " + tool.quote(text) );

Open issues

  • Is there a way to get a database/driver name from JDBC so that the appropriate QuoteTool adapter could be automatically chosen?
  • Should the quote tool do anything about start and end quotes for strings in SQL statements? All known SQL servers will accept a single quote, so it doesn't have to be. If it is, though, it needs to be optional, because it can interfere with wanting to put together a LIKE statement with.
  • It may also be that some of these are not quite complete: (What's the LIKE character in Access? How does/should it get quoted?) If you have some knowledge you can contribute, please do!

    Author:
    Robb Shecter, robb@acm.org

    public static final QuoteTool.QuoteDelegate MYSQL
    Specify MySQL syntax.

 '	--->	\'

 _    --->    \_

    HTML

    public static final QuoteTool.QuoteDelegate HTML
    Specify HTML quoting. (This is unreadable in Javadocs - see the source code to understand what transformations this quote tool makes.) 
     &	--->	&
 >	--->	>
 <	--->	<
 "	--->	"

    REGEX

    public static final QuoteTool.QuoteDelegate REGEX
    Specify Regular expression quoting. This is really just a start - it should probably also quote the "." character and others.. 
     /	--->	\/

    Specify HTTP URL quoting.

    Constructor Detail

    QuoteTool

    public QuoteTool(QuoteTool.QuoteDelegate serverType)
    Create a new QuoteTool. It must be passed one of the delegates defined in this class. For example: 
         tool = new QuoteTool(QuoteDelegate.ACCESS97);

    Parameters:
    serverType - the type of sql server in use
